p: In our data, a positive value for Sk( SPV) corresponds to epidemic pairs with R 0 < 2. Fig 4 shows that even with such small values for R 0, FI ∞ can take on a wide range of values, going up to 0.8. Yet, epidemic pairs in our data set with positive Sk( SPV) always have FI ∞ < 0.2; see Fig 5(a). This suggests that having a positive skewness, corresponding to a distribution where most of the people have low susceptibility, but a small number of people have susceptibility significantly larger than the mean, lends some protective effect to the population.
